review.title: Bootstrapping Distantly Supervised IE Using Joint Learning and Small Well-Structured Corpora
review.abstract: We propose a framework to improve performance of distantly-supervised relation extraction, by jointly learning to solve two related tasks: concept-instance extraction and relation extraction. We combine this with a novel use of document structure: in some small, well-structured corpora, sections can be identified that correspond to relation arguments, and distantly-labeled examples from such sections tend to have good precision. Using these as seeds we extract additional relation examples by applying label propagation on a graph composed of noisy examples extracted from a large unstructured testing corpus. Combined with the soft constraint that concept examples should have the same type as the second argument of the relation, we get significant improvements over several state-of-the-art approaches to distantly-supervised relation extraction.

sections.text: DIEJOB, our remote sensing system, is shown in Figure 2. We consider a common case in which most information is found in a relatively unstructured free text, but some smaller corpora exist that are well structured. DIEJOB therefore assumes that at least two corpora exist for the area of interest: a large target corpus and a smaller structured corpus that we use. Moreover, he assumes that each document in these two corpora is associated with a specific entity designated as title entity or subject. Many widely used corpora have this structure, including Wikipedia and the authoritative websites we use.

sections.heading: 2.2 Relations and Corpora
sections.text: Even large curated CBs are often incomplete, and the situation is even worse in the medical field, where coverage of large CBs such as Freebase is quite limited. We focus on extracting examples of eight relationships defined in Freebase, on drugs and diseases. The disease relationships are ToTreat, conditionsThisMayPrevent, and sideEffect, and the concept types of their second arguments are DiseaseOrMedicalCondition, DiseaseOrMedicalCondition, and Symptom. The disease relationships are hasTreatment, hasSymptom, RisCause, andpreventionFactor, with corresponding concept types such as MedicalTreatment, Symptom, RiskFactor, DiseaseCause, and ConditionPreventionFactor.We are primarily concerned with extraction from large, authoritative sources.

sections.heading: 2.5 Classifier Learning
sections.text: Given the ranking of the mention lists of these relation names from the above LP, we select the uppermost N to educate binary classifiers, which can then be used to classify the mentions of these entities (singleton lists) and coordinate the lists in a new document. We use the same feature generator for mentions and lists. Shallow characteristics include: tokens in the NPs and character prefixes / suffixes of these tokens; BOW from the sentence containing the NP; and tokens and bigrams from a window around the NP. When parsing the dependency, we find the verb closest to the head of the current NP, all modifiers of that verb and the path to that verb. In lists, the dependency characteristics are calculated relative to the head of the list.We use SVMs (Chang and Lin, 2001) and discard singleton characteristics as the most common characteristics (stop-word variant).

sections.text: Our evaluation dataset contains 20 manually labeled pages, 10 pages each from the disease corpus WikiDisease and the drug corpus DailyMed. These data were originally generated in (Bing et al., 2016).The annotated text fragments are manually filled NP, representing the second argument values of one of the eight relationships considered here, with the title drug or disease unit of the corresponding document as a relation object. The evaluation data contain 436 triples for the disease domain and 320 triples for the drug domains. sections.text: Specifically, we get triples for the disease range 2022, 2453, 905, 753 and 164 for the treatment, symptom, risk factor, cause and prevention factor. In the drug range, we get 3112, 315 and 265 triples for the use of ToTreat, ConditionThisMayPrevent and sideEffect. We have two strategies to select the top N-lists for learning the classification, one strategy selects the top N directly, without distinguishing whether they come from the structured corpus or the target corpus. It is called DIEJOB Both. The other strategy selects the top N examples only from the target corpus and is called DIEJP, without distinguishing whether they come from the structured corpus or the target corpus.

sections.heading: 3.4 Results on Labeled Pages
sections.text: The results for the precision, recall and F1 measurement are listed in Table 1. The results for the DIEBOLDS are from (Bing et al., 2016). The systems with "*" are directly aligned with the evaluation data and should be considered as ceilings for real drug performance. DIEJOB Target and DIEJOB Both are aligned with a tuning data set (details in Section 3.5). (Note that for the disease domain, DIEJOB Both and DIEJOB Both * achieve the same results because they use the same parameters even though they are aligned with other data.) DIEJOB Both outperform all other systems. Compared with MultiR, Mintz + +, and MIML-RE, the relative improvements under the F1 measurement are 22% to 30% in the disease domain, and 72% to 110% in the drug domain. The precision values of the DIEJOB Both are much higher than previous work.

sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: In order to overcome the noise in remotely designated examples (Riedel et al., 2010) introduced a "at least one" heuristic section in which instead of all mentions of a couple as correct examples, only at least one of them is taken to express this relationship. MultiR (Hoffmann et al., 2011) and MIML-RE (Surdeanu et al., 2012) expand this approach to support multiple relationships expressed by different sentences in a bag. In contrast to these approaches, DIEJOB improves the quality of training data with a boot strapping step before feeding the loud examples into a learner by using the self-confident examples from a structured corpus as seed. The benefit of this step is twofold. First, it distils the distantly designated examples by propagating labels from good seed examples, and the loud examples are weighted. Second, the propagation is distanced to further examples of relationships in the terminology that cannot be used in the reference to the words.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: We proposed the DIEJOB framework to generate good examples of remotely monitored IE. It uses the document structure of a small, well-structured corpus to collect examples of seed relationships, and it also collects concept mentions that could be the second argumentation value of relationships. DIEJOB then performs label multiplication to find mentions that can confidently be used as training examples to train classifiers for labeling new entity mentions. Experimental results show that this approach is consistent and significantly better than most modern approaches.
